summary: An FBI Albuquerque intelligence report assessing the possibility that a stolen historical church bell (the 'Death Bell') from San Jose de Gracia Church in New Mexico may have been housed at Jeffrey Epstein's Zorro Ranch. The report reviews open-source information, witness interviews, and recommends further investigative steps to locate the artifact.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Late billionaire who owned Zorro Ranch in New Mexico; his arrest and death generated global news about the ranch, which is assessed as a possible location for the stolen church bell.

persons.name: Timothy Lopez
persons.context: Interviewed in November 2019; reported seeing a bell in a real estate magazine article (2014-2015) that he believed might be the missing 'Death Bell' from Las Trampas church, and later recalled the featured home was Epstein's Zorro Ranch.

persons.name: Emilio Martinez
persons.context: Caretaker of San Jose de Gracia Church; stated in September 2019 that one of the church's two bells was stolen in the 1930s.

persons.name: Alex Lopez
persons.context: Father of Timothy Lopez; reported in September 2019 discussing with his son the possibility that the stolen 'slumber' bell was featured in a real estate magazine.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Arrested on July 2, 2020, and indicted for conspiracy to entice minors; alleged to have assisted Epstein in criminal activity at various locations including his New Mexico ranch.

persons.name: Amber Chavez
persons.context: Security guard at Zorro Ranch who, along with Cynthia Cano, contacted the Santa Fe County Sheriff's Department about a burglary attempt in June 2020.

persons.name: Cynthia Cano
persons.context: Security guard at Zorro Ranch involved in reporting a burglary attempt in June 2020.

persons.name: Jun-Lyn Fontanilla
persons.context: Worked as a housekeeper for Jeffrey Epstein; a photo from 2010 shows her and her husband Jojo with Epstein.

persons.name: Jojo Fontanilla
persons.context: Worked as a housekeeper for Jeffrey Epstein; appears in a photo with Epstein and his wife Jun-Lyn.

persons.name: Bill Powell
persons.context: Built some ranch buildings on the Zorro Ranch property for Epstein; reported that employees were sworn to secrecy about property details.

persons.name: Larry Visoski
persons.context: Epstein's personal pilot; his daughter's wedding was held at Zorro Ranch. He indicated in an FBI interview that a person named 'Bruce LNU' was the Zorro Ranch manager as of November 2006.

persons.name: Susan H. Garst
persons.context: Case Manager for the FBI investigation into the stolen bell (case 374-AQ-3179705); listed as a consumer of the report.

persons.name: Claudia Arias
persons.context: SSA listed as a consumer and reviewer of the report.

persons.name: Luther T. Seals
persons.context: SSA listed as a consumer of the report.

persons.name: Leslie 'Troy' Weber
persons.context: IPC who approved the report and is listed as a reviewer.

persons.name: Wilson
persons.context: SOS listed as a reviewer of the report.

persons.name: Amanda Nicole Young
persons.context: Case Manager for the pending FBI case 'Epstein, Jeffrey; Child Sex Trafficking' (50D-NY-3027571).

connections.description: Maxwell is described as an associate of Epstein who allegedly assisted him in criminal activity, including at his New Mexico ranch.
Jun-Lyn Fontanilla worked as Epstein's housekeeper; a photo shows her and her husband with Epstein.
Jojo Fontanilla worked as Epstein's housekeeper alongside his wife Jun-Lyn.
Visoski was Epstein's personal pilot; his daughter's wedding was held at Epstein's Zorro Ranch.
Powell built ranch buildings for Epstein on the Zorro Ranch property.
Father and son who discussed the possibility that the stolen church bell was featured in a real estate magazine.
Both were security guards at Zorro Ranch who jointly reported a burglary attempt.

events.title: Theft of 'Death Bell' from San Jose de Gracia Church
events.description: One of the two bells from the San Jose de Gracia Church in Las Trampas, New Mexico, known as the 'Death Bell' or 'Maria del Refugio', was stolen.

events.title: Timothy Lopez sees bell in real estate magazine
events.description: Timothy Lopez reads a real estate magazine article featuring a home with Spanish Colonial art, where he notices a bell he believes may be the missing church bell.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in federal prison while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: FBI interview of Timothy Lopez
events.description: Timothy Lopez is interviewed by the FBI regarding his sighting of the bell in a real estate magazine and his later recollection that the home was Epstein's Zorro Ranch.

events.title: Arrest of Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is arrested after being indicted by the U.S. District Court, Southern District of New York, for conspiracy to entice minors to travel to engage in illegal sex acts, allegedly assisting Epstein.

events.title: Burglary attempt at Zorro Ranch
events.description: A man and a woman from Artesia, New Mexico, attempt to burgle a storage container at the Zorro Ranch; security guards Amber Chavez and Cynthia Cano contact sheriff's deputies, leading to their arrest.

locations: San Jose de Gracia Mission Church, Las Trampas, New Mexico
keyFacts: The FBI assesses with medium confidence that the missing 'Death Bell' from San Jose de Gracia Church may have been housed at Jeffrey Epstein's Zorro Ranch in New Mexico.
Witness Timothy Lopez reported seeing a bell matching the description of the stolen artifact in a real estate magazine feature about a home he later identified as Epstein's Zorro Ranch.
The report indicates that photos and videos show the Zorro Ranch contained a collection of New Mexico Colonial style artwork and artifacts.
The FBI recommends interviewing housekeepers, security guards, contractors, and other individuals with access to Zorro Ranch to gather information about artifacts on the property.
The document links the investigation of the stolen bell to the broader Epstein case, noting Ghislaine Maxwell's indictment alleges criminal activity at Epstein's New Mexico ranch.
